data: Increasing the efficiency and competitiveness of organic crop breeding

ECOBREED will improve the availability of seed and varieties suitable for organic and low- input production. Activities will focus on four crop species, selected for their potential contribution to increase competitiveness of the organic sector, i.e. common wheat, potato, soybean and common buckwheat. The project will develop (a) methods, strategies and infrastructures for organic breeding, (b) varieties with improved stress resistance, resource use efficiency and quality and (c) improved methods for the production of high quality organic seed. The objectives are:
•	To increase the availability of seeds and varieties for the organic and low-input sector 
•	To identify traits and combinations of traits suited to organic and low-input production environment including high nutrient use efficiency and weed competitiveness/allelopathy
•	To increase breeding activities for organic and low-input crop production. 

ECOBREED will increase the competitiveness of the organic and low-input breeding and farming sectors by:
•	Identifying genetic and phenotypic variation in morphological, abiotic/biotic tolerance/resistance and nutritional quality traits that can be used in organic breeding
•	Evaluation of the potential of genetic variation for enhanced nutrient acquisition
•	Evaluation of the potential for increased weed competitiveness and control
•	Optimisation of seed production/multiplication via improved agronomic and seed treatment protocols
•	Developing efficient, ready-to-use farmer participatory breeding systems 
•	Pre-breeding of elite varieties for improved agronomic performance, biotic/abiotic stress resistance/tolerance and nutritional quality
•	Development of training programmes in (a) genomic tools/techniques, (b) PPB and (c) use and application of improved phenotyping capabilities. 
•	Ensuring optimum and rapid utilisation and exploitation of project deliverables and innovations by relevant industry and other user/stakeholder groups.
LIFE Little Terns - Improving the conservation status of the little tern in the UK through targeted action at the most important colonies
Royal Society for the Protection of Birds

The decline in the population of the little tern (Sterna albifrons) in the UK since the 1990s is a cause for concern. The principal threat to this shore nesting species is from human disturbance. After a decline between the 1930s and 1960s, the population recovered through protection and surveillance by wardens of breeding sites. However, in recent years the population has fallen again due to a range of factors, including disturbance, predation, habitat change and high tides linked to summer storms. There has been a reduction in the number of colonies, a loss of range in the west of the UK and, in general, there are poor levels of productivity. Sea-level rise also poses a threat to a number of current colonies. The total UK population is estimated to be less than 2 000 breeding pairs. The project will be the first nationally co-ordinated programme of action for the species, working with 29 colonies (about 65% of the total population) in 15 Special Protection Areas (SPAs) of the Natura 2000 network.

Różnorodność jest w nas - rozwój nauczycieli szansą na rozwój każdego ucznia

„Diversity is in us-teacher development as an opportunity for the development of each and every student " is a project aimed at improving the quality of teaching at the primary school level by improving the work of teachers of various subjects guided by examples of European systems of education and by learning innovative methods and forms of work, taking into account various needs of our students - including the use of ICT tools available at the school. The project was created by a project team at the Primary School No. 51 with Integrative Classes in Katowice. The need to create such a project results both from the low results achieved by our students on external examinations and from the teachers' desire to introduce and apply new teaching methods and forms of work, so as to motivate all our students better.
The project team consists of 14 teachers selected as a result of recruitment. Among them there are teachers of mathematics, science, geography, ICT, Polish, English, early school education and our school educator. Almost all team members are teachers with many years of experience who are aware of the changing school reality and the diverse needs and expectations of modern students. Therefore, they have decided to undertake the challenge of introducing changes in their didactic process by implementing innovative methods and techniques of work, using ICT and making classes more attractive in a way that would strengthen their students' motivation to develop the key competences. In order to achieve the intended goal, it is necessary to carry out professional development of this group of teachers in a way that will allow for changes in the institution.
We have chosen 7 courses giving our teachers the opportunity to acquire and improve new professional skills (linguistic, methodological, ICT, psychology etc.). Teachers will attend courses that take place in Ireland, Portugal, Italy, Greece, Norway and Malta in order to become adept in European systems of education, methods and forms of work and multiple ways to develop motivation and key competences (linguistic, mathematical and scientific-technical, IT, social and civic), as well as learning skills. The content of these teacher development courses includes the use of ICT in the didactic process, the use of games and other activating methods, working with the student with SEN, English teaching methodology, characteristics of work with the elementary school pupil as well as issues related to working with teenagers. Apart from that, 3 teachers will attend a refresher English course for teachers of other subjects - it will contain issues of introducing elements of CLIL -bilingual teaching in the classroom. The knowledge and skills acquired in the process of teacher development will allow us all  to make the classes more attractive and, as a result, to increase the students' commitment and motivation.
A valuable part of our project is the participation of our teachers in the observation of other teachers in their work during the so-called job shadowing. Our partners are schools from Italy, Spain, Great Britain, Finland and Portugal, to which pairs of teachers will be sent for observation. Our partners have important achievements in the  teaching of pupils from SEN - also those gifted ones, using ICT in the teaching process, working with eTwinning, bilingual education, using CLIL and broadly understood international cooperation. We expect that these trips will significantly contribute to the development of our teachers' competences in these areas and will enable them to see how in practice the knowledge gained during the development courses is used. What is important, the schools in Portugal, the UK and Italy also work with older students, this will give us a chance to become familiar with the specificity of working with older teenagers, who we have had at our school since last September.
The project has been planned for 22 months, during which teachers will be prepared for mobility, it will be implemented through their participation in courses and job shadowing, furthermore evaluation and project validation will take place. Thanks to the participation in the project, our teachers will undoubtedly improve their competitiveness by acquiring new skills (linguistic, communication, ICT, organization, culture and interpersonal skills). We are convinced that the increase of key competences will contribute to raising the self-esteem of all our students, the number of educational failures will drop and we will provide them with a better start to the next stages of education. Our school will benefit from participation in the Erasmus Plus program by increasing the quality of the educational offer, achieving better teaching results, raising the pedagogical competence of our staff and establishing new international contacts. On account of these activities, the school, teachers and students will be prepared for further activity on the local, national and international levels.
